prompt:
A chat between a curious user and an artificial intelligence assistant. The assistant gives helpful, detailed, and polite answers to the user's questions. USER: Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: How can I calculate the sum of an array in Java?
Please using this api: Arrays.stream.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Arrays.stream
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
int sum = Arrays.stream(array).sum();
<<<explanation>>>: The sum() method of the IntStream class returns the sum of elements in this stream. This is a special case of a reduction. This is a terminal operation.
Question: Cycling through arrayList: :BackgroundI have a sprite (an openGL quad) which 'falls' from the top of the screen to the bottom.When it gets to the bottom of the screen, it's values get reset and it starts again (from top to bottom) but moves along in the X Axis to a new X Position.WhatI'm doing is storing the X positions in an ArrayList (there could be just 1 so it falls in the same place over and over or 10 so it moves slightly every time it falls).ProblemWhat I can't work out is how to go through this arraylist and set the sprite's new X position to the value held in the 'next' arraylist position while bearing in mind that there might not be a 'next' position.So....... (and this is Pseudo code)....once sprite has fallen and it's Y position has been reset back to the top of the screen:spriteX = value_held_in_next_arrayList_position(if_there_is_one)As different levels of my game will have a different number of positions I can't explicitly say 'go to position 2' incase the arrayList is only a size of 1.  Basically what I want is to say 'go to next position' and 'if there isn't a next position' then go back to the position 0.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer: ASSISTANT:
response:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: ArrayList<Integer> arrayList = new ArrayList<>();
arrayList.add(0);
arrayList.add(1);
arrayList.add(2);
Iterator<Integer> iterator = arrayList.iterator();
while (iterator.hasNext()) {
int current = iterator.next();
if (current == 2) {
// do something
} else {
// do something else
}
}
<<<explanation>>>: The next() method of the Iterator interface returns the next element in the iteration order of the iterator. If the iterator is not yet at the end of the sequence, it returns the next element in the iteration order. If the iterator is at the end of the sequence, it returns null.
